contextId.information: Here "was with" means that Yahweh helped the people of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh was with the people of Judah

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "fail to do what I said I would do for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means he was walking rather than riding a horse or in a chariot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "prayed to Yahweh for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "be with you" is an idiom that means Yahweh will help and bless Gideon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "took control of Gideon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom is a religious oath used for emphasis that what he is about to say is true. AT: "I promise you that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "when he was very old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "And many men died of wounds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Evil turn back on their heads" is an idiom. AT: "punished the men of Shechem for all the evil they had done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: made all the evil of the men of Shechem turn back on their own heads

contextId.information: The phrase "keep adding to the times" is an idiom that means to continue to do something. You can make explicit the implicit meaning of Yahweh's saying. AT: "I will not keep on delivering you again and again" or "You can be sure that I will stop delivering you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will not keep adding to the times I deliver you

contextId.information: The phrase "made war" is an idiom which means that they attacked Israel and were at war with them. Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "attacked the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This is an idiom. Here the phrase "before Yahwheh" means that he repeated his promises as a vow before Yahweh. AT: "When Jephthah was in Mizpah he repeated all of these promises as a vow before Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: When he was before Yahweh in Mizpah, Jephthah repeated all the promises he made

contextId.information: This phrase is an idiom that means to "refuse." AT: "refused" or "denied their request" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom which means to take control of something. AT: "take control of" or "take possession of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. To do someone wrong means to do something wrong to them. AT: "treated you wrongly ... treating me wrongly" or "treated you unfairly ... treating me unfairly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: done you wrong ... doing me wrong

contextId.information: This is an idiom which means that the Spirit influenced Jephthah's decisions. AT: "the Spirit of Yahweh took control of Jephthah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the Spirit of Yahweh came on Jephthah

contextId.information: This is an idiom. To turn back on a promise means to not do what you have promised to do. AT: "I must do what I have promised" or "I cannot break my promise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I cannot turn back on my promise

contextId.information: This idiom means to burn down a house with people inside it. AT: "We will burn your house down with you still in it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: We will burn your house down over you

contextId.information: This is an idiom which means to risk one's life and to rely only on one's own strength. Jephthah continues to refer to the people of Gilead as himself. AT: "We risked our lives, relying on our own strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I put my life in my own strength

contextId.information: Here "give away ... in marriage" is an idiom which means that he allowed his daughters to get married. AT: "He had thirty daughters and arranged a marriage for each of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: He gave away thirty daughters in marriage

contextId.information: This refers to childbirth. AT: "bear a son" or "have a baby boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to childbirth. AT: "bear a son" or "have a baby boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to childbirth. AT: "bore a son" or "had a baby boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. Samson was demanding his parents to speak to the Philistine woman's parents about marriage. AT: "Now arrange for her to become my wife!" or "Make the arrangements for me to marry her!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Now get her for me to be my wife

contextId.information: The phrase "came on" means that Yahweh's Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. AT: "Yahweh's Spirit made him very strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh's Spirit suddenly came on him

contextId.information: Here the word "look" is used to draw the reader's attention to something surprising that happens in the story.  AT: "He found a swarm of bees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: And, look, there was a swarm of bees

contextId.information: This means to figure out the meaning of the riddle. AT: "can figure out its meaning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom used to get someones attention. Here "look" means to "listen." AT: "Listen to me" or "Pay attention to what I am about to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "pressured" means "urged." AT: "she kept urging him to tell her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "came on" means that Yahweh's Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. AT: "made Samson very strong" or "made Samson very powerful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to thinking. AT: "He thought to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "came on" means that Yahweh's Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. AT: "made Samson very strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "fall into the hands" means to be captured. "Those who are uncircumcised" refers to the Philistines and with the word "uncircumcised" emphasizing that they do not worship Yahweh. AT: "be captured by those godless Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: fall into the hands of those who are uncircumcised

contextId.information: This means that the spring did not dry up but that it remained. The phrase "to this day" refers to the "present" time. AT: "the spring can still be found at Lehi, even today" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: it is at Lehi to this day

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means to learn something. AT: "to understand" or "to learn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "saw" is a idiom that means to realize something. AT: "Delilah realized" (UDB) or "Delilah learned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to remember him and his situation. AT: "remember me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This idiom means that he wants to have one more powerful act against the Philistines to get full revenge for what they did to him. AT: "with one strike against the Philistine" or "in one powerful act against the Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in one blow on the Philistines

contextId.information: This means to dedicate something to a specific purpose. AT: "dedicate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "set apart" means that Micah "dedicated" or "ordained" him. AT: "Micah dedicated the Levite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "on foot" means to walk. AT: "to scout the land by walking through it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: to scout the land on foot

contextId.information: This means that something remains the same. It refers to the "present" time. AT: "and that is still its name" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means to take a break from their journey and stop at a place along the route. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:19:10|19:11]]. AT: "stop at" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means to take a break from their journey and stop at a place along the route. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:19:10|19:11]]. AT: "stopped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase means for someone to invite them to spend the night in their home. AT: "invited them to stay in their house for that night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase refers to someone inviting other people into his house to spend the night there. AT: "who has invited me to stay in his house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who will take me into his house

contextId.information: The phrase "making their hearts glad" is an idiom that means to have a good time with someone else. AT: "they were have a good time together" (UDB) or "they were enjoying themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: they were making their hearts glad

contextId.information: This word is used to get the peoples' attention. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to morning when it is bright outside. AT: "the sun was fully risen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"section by section"  The author uses this graphic description of how the Levite cut up her body into specific pieces to emphasize what he did. "Limbs" refers to a person's arms and legs. If there is not a similar phrase in your language, this description may be left out of the translation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "kill them" or "execute them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "strengthened" is an idiom that means they encouraged each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means these were particularly good soldiers. AT: "well-trained soldier" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means they trusted their men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: they were counting on the men
